questions.question: What causes a frameshift mutation?
questions.explanation: Frameshift mutations occur when nucleotides are inserted or deleted in numbers not divisible by three, shifting the reading frame.

questions.question: Why are frameshift mutations often severe?
options: They alter all downstream amino acids
They only affect one amino acid
They occur in essential genes only
questions.explanation: Because the genetic code is read in triplets, adding or removing nucleotides changes every codon from that point onward, usually creating a nonfunctional protein.

questions.question: If one nucleotide is deleted, how many amino acids are typically affected?
options: All amino acids after the deletion
questions.explanation: A single-nucleotide deletion shifts the reading frame, so every codon after the mutation is read incorrectly, changing the entire downstream sequence.

questions.question: Which mutation would NOT cause a frameshift?
questions.explanation: Adding or deleting multiples of three nucleotides inserts or removes whole amino acids but does not shift the reading frame.

questions.question: How does a frameshift differ from a point mutation?
options: Frameshift alters the reading frame; point mutation changes one codon
Frameshift is always harmful; point mutation is harmless
Frameshift occurs in DNA; point mutation in RNA
Frameshift is reversible; point mutation is permanent
questions.explanation: A point mutation (substitution) affects only one codon. A frameshift mutation (insertion/deletion) disrupts the triplet reading of all subsequent codons.

questions.question: What could reverse a frameshift caused by a single base insertion?
questions.explanation: A compensating deletion near the insertion can restore the reading frame, though the amino acid sequence between them will still be altered.

questions.question: Where would a frameshift have the smallest effect?
options: Near the end of the coding sequence
In the middle of the gene
questions.explanation: A frameshift near the end affects fewer amino acids, so the protein might retain partial function if the altered region is non-critical.

questions.question: Which disease is linked to frameshift mutations?
questions.explanation: Many cystic fibrosis cases involve a three-nucleotide deletion (not a frameshift) or frameshift mutations in the CFTR gene.

questions.question: What happens if a frameshift creates a premature stop codon?
questions.explanation: If the shifted reading frame includes a stop codon soon after the mutation, translation stops early, producing a shortened, usually nonfunctional protein.

questions.question: Can a frameshift mutation be silent?
questions.explanation: Because it changes the entire downstream amino acid sequence, a frameshift almost always significantly alters the protein, making silent frameshifts extremely rare.
